title: 108_hr2347
content: The "Children's Hope Act of 2003" allows for tax credits for contributions to education investment organizations under section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Children's Hope Act of 2003" allows for tax credits for qualified contributions to education investment organizations, with a limit of $100 for individuals ($200 for joint returns). Qualified contributions are defined as charitable donations to education investment organizations that disburse at least 90% of annual cash contributions as grants to students. The "Children's Hope Act of 2003" allows tax credits for qualified contributions to education investment organizations, disbursed as grants to students for elementary and secondary education expenses. At least half of the disbursements must go to students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. Qualified expenses are defined as per section 530(b)(4), with certain substitutions. No taxpayer can claim a credit under this section for a taxable year unless they are allowed the minimum State qualified scholarship tax credit on their State tax return. Additionally, no credit is allowed for contributions already considered for the State qualified scholarship tax credit. Special rules include no double benefit deductions and contributions are deemed made at a specific time. Taxpayers can claim a credit under this section for contributions made to an education investment organization on the last day of the preceding taxable year. Scholarships from these organizations for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses are excluded from gross income. Taxpayers can claim a credit for contributions to an education investment organization for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. Scholarships from these organizations are excluded from gross income and do not affect eligibility for Federal programs. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. Federal scholarship tax credit is conditioned on state qualified scholarship tax credit. The scholarship tax credit must meet certain requirements to be considered a State qualified scholarship tax credit, including a minimum amount of $250 per taxpayer and being allowed against State income tax or property tax. The excess credit over tax liability is also considered. The excess credit over tax liability can be carried forward for up to five years if certain conditions are met, such as not requiring the contribution to benefit a specific child and not allowing direct donations to private schools. A school tuition organization must meet specific criteria to qualify for the tax credit. The tax credit allows contributions for educational scholarships or tuition grants to children to attend qualified schools chosen by their parents. The organization must disburse at least 90% of its annual cash contributions within one year. A qualified school is one that does not discriminate and meets state requirements. An "educational scholarship or tuition grant" refers to a scholarship or grant awarded for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. The term "State" in this context refers to any of the several States.
